episodeTitle: Full of Enthusiasm! The Corrida Colosseum!
description: The Straw Hats explore Dressrosa, where Luffy encounters a mysterious blind man with gravity powers. After their belongings are stolen by 'fairies', the crew splits up. Luffy and Franky discover the Corrida Colosseum tournament, where the Mera Mera no Mi - Ace's former Devil Fruit - is revealed as the grand prize.

events.title: Issho (Fujitora) First Appearance
events.description: A blind man is introduced at a roulette table in Dressrosa, being cheated by Doflamingo's thugs who exploit his disability. Luffy exposes the deception, leading to a confrontation where the blind man reveals incredible gravity-based powers.
events.significance: First appearance of Admiral Fujitora (Issho), one of the two new admirals recruited during the timeskip through the World Military Draft. His mysterious demeanor and powerful abilities immediately establish him as a major player in the New World.

quotes.text: I appreciate your concern, young man, but I can handle myself.
quotes.speaker: Issho
quotes.context: After Luffy warns him about being cheated

events.title: Issho's Gravity Powers Revealed
events.description: The blind man defeats Doflamingo's thugs using devastating gravity-based powers, causing them to collapse under immense pressure. He channels his power through his sword, demonstrating precise control despite his blindness.
events.significance: First demonstration of the Zushi Zushi no Mi (Press-Press Fruit) abilities, establishing Fujitora as an incredibly powerful Devil Fruit user who can manipulate gravity at will.

events.title: Fairies Steal Belongings
events.description: Invisible 'fairies' steal belongings from various people in Dressrosa, including Zoro's prized sword Shusui. The toys in the town explain that the fairies are protectors of Dressrosa and are allowed to take whatever they want.
events.significance: Introduction to the Tontatta tribe mystery and sets up the subplot of Zoro pursuing his stolen sword. This event hints at the deeper secrets of Dressrosa.

quotes.text: The fairies have been the guardians of Dressrosa since the old days. They're allowed to take whatever they want.
quotes.speaker: Toy Citizen
quotes.context: Explaining the fairy thefts to the Straw Hats

events.title: Zoro Spots His Stolen Sword
events.description: Zoro catches a glimpse of his stolen sword Shusui tied to a sack being carried out a window. He, Sanji, and Kin'emon immediately give chase. Kin'emon is particularly upset as the Shusui is a national treasure of Wano Country.
events.significance: Begins the chase sequence that leads Zoro and others toward discovering the Tontatta tribe. Reinforces the importance of Shusui as a cultural artifact.

quotes.text: That's the national treasure of my country! I was planning to duel you for it!
quotes.speaker: Kin'emon

events.title: Thunder Soldier Debut
events.description: A one-legged toy soldier appears in front of the Corrida Colosseum, shooing children away and warning them that the Colosseum is too brutal for them. He is then chased by guards as he himself is a wanted criminal.
events.significance: First appearance of Kyros in his Thunder Soldier form, though his true identity remains hidden. This mysterious character will play a crucial role in Dressrosa's history and rebellion.

quotes.text: Stay away from here, children! This place is too brutal for young eyes!
quotes.speaker: Thunder Soldier
quotes.context: Warning children away from the Colosseum

events.title: Luffy and Franky Reach the Corrida Colosseum
events.description: While interrogating one of the defeated thugs about the SMILE factory, Luffy and Franky learn about a tournament at the Corrida Colosseum. They decide to investigate and arrive at the massive gladiatorial arena.
events.significance: Introduces the Corrida Colosseum, a central location for much of the Dressrosa Arc. Sets up the tournament that will occupy a significant portion of the arc.

events.title: Gatz Introduction
events.description: Gatz, the enthusiastic announcer of the Corrida Colosseum, appears to commentate the tournament. His energetic personality and professional announcing style add excitement to the arena.
events.significance: Introduces Gatz, who will serve as the tournament's narrator and later play a supportive role during the final battle against Doflamingo.

quotes.text: Welcome, ladies and gentlemen, to the Corrida Colosseum!
quotes.speaker: Gatz

events.title: Mera Mera no Mi Revealed as Tournament Prize
events.description: At the opening ceremony of the Corrida Colosseum tournament, Gatz dramatically unveils the grand prize: the Mera Mera no Mi, the Flame-Flame Fruit that once belonged to Portgas D. Ace. The revelation shocks Luffy and the entire audience.
events.significance: This is a pivotal moment that changes Luffy's entire mission in Dressrosa. Doflamingo is using Ace's former Devil Fruit as bait to lure Luffy and disrupt his alliance with Law. The emotional weight of Ace's fruit being up for grabs forces Luffy to make a critical decision.

quotes.text: Today's prize for the winner of this tournament is none other than... the Mera Mera no Mi! The legendary Flame-Flame Fruit that once belonged to Fire Fist Ace!
quotes.speaker: Gatz

events.title: Luffy Decides to Enter the Tournament
events.description: Upon seeing Ace's Devil Fruit offered as a prize, Luffy becomes visibly emotional and enraged. Despite knowing he cannot eat the fruit himself, he becomes determined to enter the tournament to ensure Ace's power doesn't fall into the wrong hands.
events.significance: This decision demonstrates Luffy's deep connection to Ace and his protective nature toward his brother's legacy. It also plays directly into Doflamingo's plan to distract Luffy from the alliance's mission.

quotes.text: I won't let anyone have Ace's power! I'm entering this tournament!
quotes.speaker: Luffy
quotes.context: Declaring his intention to fight for the Mera Mera no Mi

events.title: Flashback to Ace and the Mera Mera no Mi
events.description: Brief flashbacks show Ace using his Flame-Flame Fruit powers, reminding viewers of his signature Fire Fist technique and his role as Second Division Commander of the Whitebeard Pirates. The flashback emphasizes the emotional significance of the fruit's reappearance.
events.significance: Reinforces the emotional stakes of the tournament for Luffy and reminds the audience of Ace's legacy. The fruit's reappearance symbolizes both Ace's death and the continuation of his will.

themes.description: The episode powerfully explores Luffy's connection to Ace through the reappearance of the Mera Mera no Mi. Luffy's emotional reaction and determination to protect Ace's Devil Fruit demonstrates his enduring love for his brother and desire to honor his memory.
themes.symbolism: The Mera Mera no Mi represents Ace's legacy - both his power and his will. Its appearance as a tournament prize symbolizes how others might exploit or dishonor that legacy, forcing Luffy to take action.

themes.description: Issho's intervention against the cheating thugs introduces his personal code of justice, which will prove more complex and nuanced than typical Marine absolutes. His blindness serves as a metaphor for his unique perspective on justice.
themes.symbolism: Issho's blindness represents his choice to not 'see' the corruption in the world through conventional means, but instead to sense the truth of people's hearts and actions.
culturalReferences: Zatōichi - the blind swordsman from Japanese cinema

themes.description: The episode establishes Dressrosa as a land of secrets - from the mysterious 'fairies' to the wanted Thunder Soldier to the living toys. Nothing in Dressrosa is quite what it appears to be.
themes.symbolism: The invisible fairies stealing things represents the hidden forces at work in Dressrosa, manipulating events behind the scenes.

characterSpotlights.development: Luffy's reaction to the Mera Mera no Mi reveals how deeply Ace's death still affects him. His immediate decision to enter the tournament shows his protective nature and his refusal to let Ace's legacy be dishonored.
keyActions: Exposes the cheating at the roulette table
Sees the Mera Mera no Mi and becomes determined to win it
quotes: I won't let anyone have Ace's power! I'm entering this tournament!

characterSpotlights.development: Fujitora is introduced as a powerful and enigmatic figure. His blindness, humility, and devastating power immediately establish him as a complex character who defies simple categorization.
keyActions: Is cheated at roulette due to his blindness
Defeats the thugs with gravity powers
Mysteriously departs without revealing his identity
quotes: I appreciate your concern, young man, but I can handle myself.

characterSpotlights.development: Zoro's pursuit of his stolen sword drives his subplot and separates him from Luffy, setting up his own adventures in Dressrosa.
keyActions: Begins chase with Sanji and Kin'emon

mangaDifferences.difference: The anime extends the chase sequence with Zoro, Sanji, and Kin'emon pursuing the fairies, showing more detail about how Kin'emon becomes separated from the group.
In the manga, Thunder Soldier directly fires at children at the colosseum entrance, but in the anime this is changed to warning shots to make the scene less intense.
The anime adds additional dialogue and reactions from the crowd when the Mera Mera no Mi is revealed to heighten the dramatic impact.

trivia.fact: This episode marks the first appearance of Admiral Fujitora (Issho), one of the two new admirals recruited during the two-year timeskip through the World Military Draft.
The Zushi Zushi no Mi (Press-Press Fruit) is one of the most powerful Paramecia-type Devil Fruits, allowing the user to manipulate gravity and even summon meteors from space.

sources.title: Zushi Zushi no Mi - One Piece Wiki

trivia.fact: Issho blinded himself intentionally because he had seen too many atrocities in the world and could no longer bear to witness them. This self-inflicted blindness reflects his complex moral philosophy.

sources.title: Why Did Fujitora Blind Himself in One Piece?

trivia.fact: The Mera Mera no Mi's reappearance occurs exactly two years after Ace's death at Marineford, as Devil Fruits reincarnate into nearby fruits when their user dies.

sources.title: Mera Mera no Mi - One Piece Wiki

trivia.fact: This episode is part of the opening of the Dressrosa Arc, which would become one of the longest arcs in One Piece, spanning 118 episodes (629-746) in the anime.
Ikuya Sawaki, Fujitora's Japanese voice actor, was 62 years old when he first voiced the character, bringing gravitas and depth to the admiral's performance.
The episode is based on Chapters 701 and 702 of the manga, which were part of Volume 71.
The opening theme 'Wake up!' by AAA debuted in episode 629 and would continue through episode 686, making it one of the longer-running opening themes in One Piece.
